TEXT: The applicant is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by PERSON , barrister - at - law , instructed by PERSON , ORG , GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent , PERSON , ORG , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant is a heavy gambler on horses and often held large sums of money in cash for this purpose . Apart from his winnings , the applicant also inherited a large sum in cash from his father in DATE and in DATE realised a substantial profit on the sale of a house which he bought and had refurbished .

The applicant states that he has never been convicted of any drugs - related offences and maintains that he was wrongly prosecuted and convicted in relation to the handling of cash stolen from a post office in DATE . He was given a DATE prison sentence and was released in DATE .

In DATE , and in order to avoid off - course betting duty , the applicant decided to open an account under a pseudonym with a specialist bookmaker who conducted business inside racetracks . The applicant on occasions attended race meetings carrying large sums of money . According to the applicant , in DATE he had , mainly through his winnings , over GBP CARDINAL available to him for betting .

The applicant also used his bookmaker ’s account for placing bets over the telephone . Such bets were deemed to be off - course bets and were thus subject to tax . Having ascertained that he could avoid tax on off - course betting by gambling off - shore as a non - resident , the applicant decided to buy property in GPE and contacted a lawyer in GPE to this end .
The applicant arranged a meeting with the lawyer in GPE for DATE . After the meeting the applicant intended to go to a race meeting in GPE .

Having discovered that his partner ’s brother , H , was intending to take DATE in GPE , and being nervous about taking the money himself , the applicant enlisted H ’s help in taking GBP CARDINAL to GPE as a favour . According to the applicant , he wanted to look at properties in southern GPE in the price range ORG MONEY and required the rest for the race meeting in GPE . The applicant arranged to meet H in GPE .

On DATE H , who was driving a hired car , was stopped at GPE by a ORG and Excise Officer . When asked how much cash he was carrying , H replied GBP CARDINAL . A subsequent search of the boot of the car revealed GBP CARDINAL in a green hold - all . H stated that the sum in question belonged to a friend who was meeting him in GPE .

H was subsequently questioned about the money by ORG and Excise officials . H stated that the money belonged to the applicant , that he was taking it out of the country for the applicant , that the latter wanted to use it to buy an apartment in GPE and that he was travelling to GPE and GPE .
The money seized was sent for forensic testing and the sum of GBP CARDINAL was deposited with ORG on DATE .

The applicant contacted the ORG and Excise authorities to reclaim the money and attended voluntarily for interview on DATE together with his solicitor . On that occasion the applicant was told that he was not under arrest . He answered the questions put to him and gave permission to examine his bank accounts as well as his account with his bookmaker .

An order for the detention of the applicant ’s money was granted by ORG on DATE on application of the ORG and Excise authorities pursuant to section ORG ) of LAW DATE . A further order was made on DATE .

In DATE the ORG and Excise authorities made an application under section CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE for the forfeiture of GBP CARDINAL seized from the applicant on the grounds that its officers believed that the money was directly or indirectly the proceeds of drugs trafficking and/or was intended for use in drug trafficking . On CARDINAL and DATE ORG made an order for the confiscation of the sum in question and ordered the applicant to pay the costs of the hearing .
The applicant ’s appeal was heard before GPE ORG on CARDINAL and DATE . The court upheld the forfeiture order and made an order that the applicant pay a further amount towards costs .

In the applicant ’s opinion , ORG did not find that he or H were going to use the money to purchase drugs but that it was satisfied , on the civil standard of proof , that some unidentified third party was going to use it for this purpose . The Government draw attention to their view that ORG did find that the cash was intended for use in drug trafficking . According to the Government , ORG noted that the money was contaminated to a limited extent by cannabinoids and that H had with him in the hire car a plan showing a route through GPE to GPE . The Government further observe that the cash seized included a large proportion of NORP notes , which are typically used by drug - traffickers to finance drug deals conducted abroad , and that the south coast of GPE is known to ORG officials as the source of a large number of consignments of drugs destined for GPE . For the Government , and having regard to the strong circumstantial evidence , ORG found the explanations given by the applicant and H as to why cash was being carried by H to GPE wholly unbelievable . Thus , ORG concluded :
“ We do find it more probable than not that this money was to be used for trafficking . ”
The applicant observes that ORG would appear not to have commented on precisely who they believed would be responsible for using the money for drug purchase .

The Government also point out that , as regards the applicant ’s claim that he had over GBP CARDINAL available to him for gambling in DATE ( see above ) , the only documentary evidence produced by him in relation to his finances showed that he had lost MONEY CARDINAL DATE , a further GBP CARDINAL,CARDINAL in DATE , and a further GBP CARDINAL in DATE . The Government state that the applicant has produced no evidence at all to substantiate his claim that he made substantial winnings on cash bets since DATE . According to the Government , at the time of the forfeiture of his cash the applicant was receiving social security benefits of approximately GBP DATE .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE provides as follows :
“ A customs officer or constable may seize and , in accordance with this section , detain any cash which is being imported into or exported from GPE if -
( a ) its amount is not less than the prescribed sum - and
( b ) he has reasonable grounds for suspecting that it directly or indirectly represents any person ’s proceeds of drug trafficking , or is intended by any person for use in drug trafficking . ”

The term “ exported ” has an extended meaning and includes cash “ being brought to any place in GPE for the purpose of being exported ” ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) . The prescribed sum referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) is GBP CARDINAL .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the same LAW states :

“ Cash seized by virtue of this section shall not be detained for TIME unless its continued detention is authorised by an order made by a justice of the peace ... ; and no such order shall be made unless the justice ... is satisfied that
( a ) that there are reasonable grounds for the suspicion mentioned in subsection ( CARDINAL ) above ; and

( b ) that continued detention of the cash is justified while its origin or derivation is further investigated or consideration is given to the institution ( whether in GPE or elsewhere ) of criminal proceedings against any person for an offence with which the cash is connected . ”

The order can not endure DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) ) , but further orders can be made by the court provided the total period of detention does not exceed DATE from DATE first order ( section FAC ) ) . These powers may be used even if no criminal proceedings have been instituted ( or even contemplated ) against any person for a drug trafficking offence in connection with the money seized .

The person from whom the cash was seized , or any person on whose behalf the cash was being exported or imported , may apply to the GPE court for the money to be released on the basis that there are no reasonable grounds for suspecting that it directly or indirectly represents any ORG proceeds of drugs trafficking or is intended by any person for use in drug trafficking ( sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) ) . Where an application is made to forfeit the money , the cash seized and detained is not to be released until the relevant proceedings have been concluded ( and so overrides the DATE restriction set out in section QUANTITY ) ) .
Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) A GPE court ... may order the forfeiture of any cash which has been seized under section CARDINAL of this Act if satisfied , on an application made while the cash is detained under that section , that the cash directly or indirectly represents any person ’s proceeds of drug trafficking , or is intended by any person for use in drug trafficking .

( CARDINAL ) The standard of proof in proceedings on an application under this section shall be that applicable to civil proceedings ; and an order may be made under this section whether or not proceedings are brought against any person for an offence with which the cash in question is connected . ”

Direct evidence is not required to establish that cash seized pursuant to section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act is the proceeds of drug trafficking or is intended for use in drug trafficking . The court may draw inferences from circumstantial evidence , so long as the evidence is sufficient to establish the case to the requisite ( civil ) standard of proof , namely the balance of probabilities . According to domestic case - law , this is a flexible test which is to be adapted to meet the nature and seriousness of the allegations made ( see Re H [ CARDINAL ] PERSON , per Lord PERSON ) .
The legal burden of proof rests on the relevant authorities seeking a detention or forfeiture order .

An appeal against the making of a forfeiture order by a GPE court lies to ORG . Appeals to ORG are by way of rehearing . A party to proceedings may apply to a GPE court for an order permitting the use of cash which has been seized and detained to pay for legal representation on appeal before ORG ( section CARDINAL ) ) .

A party to the proceedings who wishes to appeal the decision of ORG to make a forfeiture order may apply to ORG by way of case stated . ORG on an appeal by way of case stated may overturn the decision of ORG if it is erroneous in law or in excess of jurisdiction ( section CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ) . A party to the proceedings may also apply to ORG by way of judicial review to have the decision of ORG quashed on established public law grounds including error of law , procedural unfairness or irrationality ( section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ) . A further appeal lies ( with the permission of the court ) from ORG to ORG and then to ORG .
